Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
You might have had a null byte that just happened to be there, without you putting it in place. When getting memory from the operating system, it usually is zeroed. So variables in a memory location your programme uses for the first time are kind of initialised to zeroes, it's just nothing you can rely on, leads to undefined behaviour if you do. Those are the kind of things that break if you change something in another part seemingly not connected, because suddenly this memory is not new, but reused, and has prior data in it.
Possible the checking environment caused the malfunction that way.
Later introduced tool `valgrind` would often detect using uninitialised data. I think that's in week 4, when topic is "memory".

Content: yeah that's the general idea.  it does get tricky with how to make that all happen.  you're going to need to use a lot of arrays (or at least I did).  Try thinking of the letters as their ASCII equivalents (pull up a chart for this problem set) instead of the letters themselves.  Then, you're going to need to perform manipulations on those numbers to get them all upper or lower case, first (as you can accept either upper or lower case key but shouldn't change output). Keeping track of upper/lower case and all of the filters to reject bad user input are also best accomplished with loops/arrays as well.

here is pseudocode with a spoiler 
||create a truth table array initialized with all zeros
iterate over the key string
    get the alpha index value for each character, A = 0, B = 1, etc.
    increment the truth table index for each alpha index
iterate over the truth truth table
    check if each index of the truth table is greater than 1
        if it is print an error
        return||
